speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first today in Maryland versus Blake. Ms. Graeff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Now, what has to be considered, by way of evidence, in evaluating whether the suspect has initiated the additional conversation?  Is it appropriate, in  this case, to consider the age of the person?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- and the fact that, on the charges which he saw, it said he was subject to the death penalty, but that was not correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: It would not --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- you would not consider it in connection with the initiation --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Counsel --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I suppose that if they knowingly put death on in order to get him off his balance,  -- that would be badgering, wouldn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- the initial question Justice O'Connor asked is, Do we consider these other factors?  And then -- but you're talking now about curing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then why consider age?  I mean, the -- both of them go to the same point, and that is, What would a reasonable person suppose the suspect's understanding was at that point?  And would it be fair to conclude that the suspect was, in fact, initiating conversation, rather than responding to the police or doing something irrational?  And I don't see why the -- in effect, the false statement about the death penalty -- or true statement about the death penalty, for that matter -- doesn't go to the same point, just as the suspect's age goes to it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- but the trial judge made certain findings.  He heard these witnesses.  He heard the police officers.  And he suggested that the -- Police Officer Reese was playing a good-cop/bad-cop game with Detective Johns. And so, that this -- the statement made by Reese, "You'll want to talk to us now, huh?" was designed to elicit an answer.  And the trial court also said there is an additional factor, and that is this charge, that was intimidating even if it didn't have death on it, wasn't presented to Blake immediately.  It could have been presented when he was put in the cell, initially.  So, there were those factors.  Those are relevant, are they not, to the character of what Blake said?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the factors that I mentioned?  Would they be relevant to a factfinder's determining what a reasonable person in that situation -- with the two police officers appearing, with the charges not being presented immediately, not being presented at the time the Miranda warnings were given, but only after  -- would those be -- would those be relevant factors to decide if this was a  voluntary initiated request to talk to the police?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- it has to be --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- you're making --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- voluntary at some -- if you held the man's hand to a burning iron, we would -- we'd say that's not voluntary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, it has to be voluntary, certainly, in the lay sense of the term.  Then the law has certain accretive force when we talk about, you know, involuntary as a matter of law.  But what we're -- what we're talking about, it seems to me, is, rather, a commonsense inquiry as to whether or not it was voluntary, as to which I don't think you necessarily lose your case, but it seems to me that at least these have to be considered in determining whether or not it's voluntary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but I -- you can't initiate something involuntarily and have that count, can you?  You say

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- let's say involuntarily, in the lay sense of the word, in the common sense of the word, where it was actually physically coerced.  That wouldn't count.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but what about --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no, it's the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the first step?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- first part of the analysis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: How --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The first part of the analysis is whether or not he initiates.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And you're trying to tell us that the initiation can be involuntarily?  I just don't -- I just don't agree with that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: All right.  But suppose the police are twisting his arm behind his back until he initiates a further discussion.  You would say that's fine?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, you have to concede --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Aren't you -- aren't you confusing Miranda, which is a question of comprehension followed by voluntary waiver, with the question of initiation?  They are separate questions.  And what our -- what we are trying to get at is:  If there is going to be an initiation on the suspect's part, doesn't it have to be a voluntary initiation?  Your answer consistently is, Did he know that questioning would stop?  And those are two different issues.  One is understanding Miranda warnings.  One is voluntarily initiating a further conversation with the police.  So, I don't see it -- let's assume he perfectly understood the Miranda warnings.  But if the initiation was not a voluntary initiation, or an initiation at all, it seems to me you lose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. Graeff, is there any case which says that an initiation is not voluntary, as opposed to a confession being not voluntary, because the suspect has been charged with a crime greater than what the police believe they can prove, or if the police advise him that he's been charged with a greater crime than what he's really been charged with? Is there any case which says that the effect of that is to cause his initiation of discussion to be involuntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do you take --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I â€“-

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- the position that initiation is a purely formal inquiry, a matter of magic words?  If he says the equivalent of, "I guess I'll talk to you," that's all you look at?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- answer my question.  Is that all you look at?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- you're avoiding my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: My question is, Is the act of initiation a purely formal act on your view, so that so long as the suspect says the magic words, it doesn't matter what is in his mind or what he understands?  Is it formal or not formal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It's not formal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, can I interrupt with --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I think we can --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- with one --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- I think that's a given. The question is whether or not he agrees -- he indicates affirmatively that he wants to begin talking.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- the issue, it seems to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, now suppose -- I don't understand all these legal terms here.  Imagine. [Laughter.]

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It may be close to the truth.  Now, we have a case, a hypothetical.  The defendant is sitting there, the police say, "Question?"  And he says, "I want to see my lawyer."  And the policeman says the following, "That's fine, go ahead, we'll get him.  By the way, if you see him, we'll execute you.  Are you sure you don't want to talk to us?" That's plainly unlawful, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, the same thing happens, but what he says is, "You'd better talk to us, or you'll be executed.  Think about it."  Equally unlawful, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, a minute --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- passes while he's thinking about it.  Okay?  Is it -- is it unlawful now, because a minute has passed before he says yes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I just --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't -- I don't want legalism. I just want the conclusion.  A minute has passed before he says yes.  Has that changed everything, and it becomes lawful?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No.  Now it's 15 minutes.  Now it's 30 minutes.  Okay?  Now, a court says 30 minutes is the same as one minute, "We don't think the passage of 29 extra minutes made a difference."  And what's your reply?  Not in legalism. You're going to say, "Oh, no, the passage of 30 minutes, rather than 1 minute, makes all the difference."  And I would like to know why.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, that's fine.  I'm not -- I'm - - I want you to say that kind of thing.  You're saying it's not just 30 minutes, it's "also some other things happened."  What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- improper statement was, "I bet you want to talk now, huh?"

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right?  And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- immediately, the other detective, Johns -- immediately?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Said what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- possible.  That definitely cuts  in your favor, unless, of course, it sounds like a good- cop/bad-cop routine.  And --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: There was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- people --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- there was no finding that this was a good-cop/bad-cop --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- routine, was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In fact, there was a finding that Johns' testimony was credible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- subjectively true.  And so, I'd simply wonder if the fact that it's subjectively true, and there is a finding that the defendant -- here, we have 30 minutes, and we have the fact that the other detective said, "He said he can't talk to us.  We can't do anything about it." We have that.  Is there anything else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Right.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- we have a passage --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you two rather elementary questions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: One of the issues is whether  -- when he spoke and said, "Can I talk now?" -- was that voluntary or not?  Who has the burden on whether it was, or not, voluntary, the State or the defendant, in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And so, the State did have the burden.  And what is your view on the fact that the trial -- the judge who heard the evidence said they had not met the burden?  What kind of deference is owing to that finding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I -- before we get to that, I read the trial court's opinion, and it didn't seem to me that it was playing, as Justice Breyer said, this game of legal words and labels.  It was saying, "There are things to suspect here.  Yes, I credited Detective Johns.  But he was asked, 'Why did you bring along Reese?  You didn't need him?'"  And there was no answer to that. And there was also no explanation, after they left Blake in his cell, Reese just having said, "I bet you want to talk to us now, huh?" -- there was nothing said to assure Blake that that was not a "You'd better talk to us, or you're going to be in trouble" kind of thing.  There was just the statement by Blake and another Miranda warning.  All of those things, the judge said, weighed on his mind, and he reached the conclusion that the Government hadn't sustained its burden on the basis of those factors. So, is that clearly erroneous?  I mean, don't we defer to the judge's findings?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Graeff. Mr. Feldman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, tell us --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- what factors, in your view, can be considered.  The --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: The defendant's age?  The improper charge?  What else can be considered?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but what we're trying to determine is, What do you consider in determining whether he has -- a reasonable person initiating --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- further discussion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, I'm not so sure, because a voluntary waiver is measured against a Miranda warning.  And, by definition here, you don't have a Miranda warning, because we're asking about "whether initiation."  So, it seems to me there's a threshold inquiry of voluntariness to determine whether or not there was a voluntary initiation, and that that -- it does not comprehend or require a Miranda warning. Otherwise, you're double counting.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I agree with that.  But I want -- what I think the Court is trying to find is some explanation of the threshold test for determining whether or not there was a voluntary initiation.  Now, I think we agree -- or at least I agree -- that there shouldn't be any Miranda warnings required. That doesn't go into the mix.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Any new Miranda warning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But, Mr. --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- Feldman, do you agree that the State had the burden of proving voluntariness at the second stage?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And why -- and why should we not credit the finding of fact by the -- by the trial judge --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- who found it was not voluntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The middle level --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- said there was no Edwards violation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, that doesn't contribute anything to the dialogue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, you just told me you agree that the burden was on the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- State to prove voluntariness. But I still haven't heard your answer to why we should not credit the finding of fact by the trial judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I don't care --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- what the Maryland Court of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- Appeals said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The highest court in Maryland also credited the finding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, in any event, we have a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- a finding of fact by the trial court before us, and I don't -- I still don't understand.  From your point of view, why shouldn't we credit that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You disagree with the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- finding that -- the -- isn't it -- aren't we entitled to give a -- some presumption of validity?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Because it's a mixed question of law and fact --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- and not a purely factual

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- determination.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you're going to the standard, which is, I think, the -- actually, the difficult question here, what's wrong -- should you say -- what's wrong with saying -- which is what I was pursuing  -- that, where there is a question that's improper, as there was here, by the police, the only real question is, Is a later initiation "the fruit"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And you say the State has to show it wasn't the fruit.  That would have the virtue of making the law quite consistent here, as it is with Fourth Amendment/Fifth Amendment cases.  That's a well known concept.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why -- I understand that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- there's a lot of language --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but the standard fruit analysis is when you get something like a statement, and that statement then leads to further evidence.  We're not -- I mean, Justice Breyer wasn't using the fruits analysis in that sense.  He was -- he was getting at the -- at the same question we're all trying to get at:  Was the later so-called initiation the product of the improper police comment in the first place, or was it voluntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I realize that.  But you concede -- I think you concede that the -- that the so-called initiation has got to be a voluntary initiation.  You don't take the position that it's merely magic words.  Isn't that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right.  If that is correct, why do we not give some deference to the conclusion of the trial court that this was not voluntary?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You say there was a legal error. What exactly was the legal error?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What did it --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- overlook?  What did it overlook?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's always true in every Edwards case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- that's a wash.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What else did --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- it miss?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, Mr. Feldman --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- I have to interrupt.  They did not overlook that he had been given the Miranda warning.  She expressly commented on the fact that an hour and 17 minutes had lapsed since that time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, how --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- was it that she --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- overlooked that?  I just don't get it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: They --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You know, the evidence is undisputed that one officer made the statement, another officer said no, they left, 30 minutes went by.  What exactly did she overlook?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're saying that those facts could not reasonably be found to be -- to produce a situation in which the defendant believed he would be hounded to talk, so he said, "What the heck, I'll talk."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is what Edwards is directing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That no factfinder -- and this is mixed fact and law -- could reasonably come to that conclusion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: When it -- when one of the -- the last he had heard from the officers was, "No, he doesn't want to talk.  He already asked for a lawyer.  We cannot talk to him now."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're saying no reasonable judge could find that that defendant thought he would be hounded.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it doesn't count --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Feldman, it doesn't count as badgering, or the equivalent, that the police -- the -- walk in, and they present not only the charges, but they present the application for the charges, which shows that the co- perpetrator had talked to the police, talked his head off, and put all the blame, at every step on the way, on this defendant? That did weigh heavily in the trial judge's mind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And is -- was that improper to take into account?  How would a reasonable person in this situation feel?"  Would he feel that he was impelled to speak, because the co-perpetrator had --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It has nothing to do with whether the defendant thinks he is going to be hounded.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It has --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- to do with --  --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- with whether --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the defendant thinks he will be badgered and badgered until he finally talks.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is what Edwards is directed at.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, Edwards is directed at avoiding badgering, but the issue before us is initiation. That's not a question of badgering, it's a question of initiation.  And don't the points that Justice Ginsburg raised go to whether the initiation is likely to have been a voluntary initiation?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Feldman. Mr. Ravenell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if it --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if, instead of the half hour or so, 24 hours had passed and they got a call from the defendant, said, "I want to talk now"?  Still, is that -- is that initiation on his part?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Of course, that factor --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- if you can --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- can work the other way.  You would be up here, saying, "Oh, he had 24 hours.  He thought he was going to get the death penalty.  He knew the other man was turning on him to implicate him in the murder.  His agony was increasing."  I mean, I -- it seems to me the question is whether or not the curative measures were adequate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Of course, you know, we can play the game -- 5 minutes, 20 minutes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- 30 minutes.  We know that. But, it seems to me, when 30 minutes passed here, there were curative measures.  Now, you say, at the outset, there can never be a -- curative measures.  That -- I don't think you have anything to -- any support for that in the case law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A cure --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A cure of --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would have thought --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sorry, go on.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I would have thought you would have said, then, 24 hours doesn't make a difference.  If there can never be a cure, if there's a violation because the question from Reese constitutes interrogation, and you're telling us there's no cure, it doesn't matter how long it is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A cure of what?  That's what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- it seems to me, a lot of this discussion has come down to.  What are you curing?  Are you curing involuntariness of the confession, or are you curing the police badgering?  I thought that we were just trying to cure the badgering and then let the voluntariness of the confession be decided as voluntariness is normally decided, for which purpose you would take into account that he's been -- erroneously said he was charged with murder, or whatever.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, assuming --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- there was --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- assuming there was overreaching on the part of Officer Reese, my question is, Is there any circumstance in which that overreaching can be cured? And I thought your answer is that, yes, that with the sufficient passage of time, it can be cured.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, once Officer --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- once Officer Reese made his comment, there was no circumstance, even a week, a month --  -- relatives come in and say, "We think you ought to talk," no intervening circumstance -- once there is that one sentence of overreaching, he can never initiate contact -- discussion with

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- the police.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're not helping --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- defendants, you know.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In some cases, you are not helping defendants.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Sometimes, a defendant, after he talks to his relatives, might conclude, "Boy, you know, I'd better cooperate with the police and get a lesser sentence." But you're saying that can't happen.  Once --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- once the police make a misstatement, he can never come forward and say, "I want to confess."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Ravenell --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- you are defending a judgment that no court in Maryland, as far as I know, ever made.  All of the courts thought that the law was, yes, the taint of an improper question by the police can be removed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, let's take the case as it comes to us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The taint can be removed.  That is the law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Accepting that to be the law, what, in your judgment, would it take to remove the taint?  -- the taint here being the statement that Office Reese made.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- suppose, again, we do not accept that position.  You need another fallback position in our -- in order to argue the case before us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, Johns --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- Johns, in effect, did that here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Certainly, one of the best curative devices is immediate correction from a superior.  And  that is exactly what happened here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So, you think you'd have a stronger case if Johns hadn't corrected Reese?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- that's a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- far stretch.  It's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you don't want the --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- you don't want the officer talking to Blake directly.  I thought that would be another violation.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But it seems --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- to me that it's a bit much to say that the problem is that the -- he didn't talk to Blake directly, because that gets into another extended dialogue with the defendant that the defendant has not initiated.  It seems it's much better, in the defendant's presence, to do what Johns did here, which is to rebuke Reese for the interrogation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- what about just simple thing like this, that there is an implication in what Reese said, that he listens to in his cell, "I guess you'd -- he'll want to talk to us now, huh?"  The implication is that he faces death, and he'll be better off by talking to them without a lawyer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, suppose Johns had said to the defendant, "Mr. Blake, I want to tell you something.  My colleague here has implied that you will be better off, because of the death possibility, in talking to us without a lawyer.  We want to tell you, that isn't true.  There is no way that you'll be better off talking to us without a lawyer.  You will be at least equally, from your point of view, as well off if you talk to a lawyer."  Now, that might have cured it, I guess.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The right direction would be to say, "Please don't talk to us."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, there's no dispute about the historical facts found by the judge.  Everybody agrees this is the dialogue that took place, this is the time that it took place.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Those are factual questions. It's a very different question of what the significance of that is under the Edwards initiation rule.  So, it's not an issue of deference to the trial-court judge.  We know what the facts are.  We're deferring to those findings of fact.  It's a question of what the legal significance is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what the Chief Justice says was true in Bradshaw and in Edwards and in Elstad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All questions, which were mixed questions of law and fact, where this Court took the words, took the facts, and made a rule.  And that's this case.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, just to -- stop there. Why is the trial court better suited to apply the Edwards rule to a set of facts that we would -- we accept based on deference to the factfinder?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, are you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- arguing that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- are you arguing that trial court, even though there's agreement -- understanding on most of the historical facts, is still in a better position to make the judgment call as to whether it was voluntary or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What was the quote from the SG's brief?  I didn't --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And what did they say?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe they said that.  I'd be surprised if they said that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you tell us --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- where you're reading from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, if there was a judicial finding that any statement given was --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- coerced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We're talking about the confession  being coerced, that the statement given was coerced --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- not that his decision to talk to the police was coerced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, we're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- only talking --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- about what the SG has conceded.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He has conceded that if the -- if it is found by the court that the statement given was a --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- coerced statement, in that event, it would be unusable for any purpose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And the -- and the Court of Appeals of Maryland said, "We're going to look at this in the legal sense, not the dictionary sense."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And that's what we're reviewing  here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but if you're looking -- if you're taking your standard seriously --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The reason that my -- I was able to give my hypothetical before --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- the reason that you'd have to say, "You will not be better off -- you will not be worse off in respect to the death penalty, by -- you know, we -- it won't" --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- "make you any better off to talk to the lawyer" -- Sorry.  Strike. The reason that the policeman, to cure, would have to say, "Look, it's not going to help you, in respect to the death penalty, to talk without your lawyer," is because that was the implication of his question, that was the implication - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- of the wrongful statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The implication was, "You're not going to get death if you talk to us without a lawyer."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But if it had been some other questions, some questions, for example, about the crime, all you would have had to do was eliminate whatever negative  implication came out of those questions, which might have been nothing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So timely --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But there is no finding to support the suggestion that it was just the death penalty that concerned him.  He was also concerned, I thought, about the fact that his accomplice, Tolbert, had implicated him, and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- presumably implicated him  --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- too far.  So is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: There's just no finding that it was simply the death penalty that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- his concern with Tolbert was a wholly legitimate reason for him to want to talk to the police and --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- get things straightened away right away.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right, so --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- maybe you should modify the standard.  Maybe the standard ought to be that where you have an improper line of questioning, after the warning, that the police either have to negative the implication of those questions, the relevant implication, or the State has to show that some other series of independent events, such as Justice Kennedy mentioned, made the difference.  That is, caused the later request to talk without a lawyer.  And if they can't show the one or the other, then they lose.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I interrupt --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- you with a -- with a question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You seem to have taken the position that the State cannot cure an Edwards violation, which seems to me quite different from the trial court's ruling, because the trial court made a number of factual statements that seem to me to be saying, "Had these things been done, the violation might have been a -- cured."  She referred to the fact he was still undressed, still in a cold cell, that his parent -- there was no parent present.  He was scared, and -- he was scared and thought he was facing death.  Now, it seems to me the logical inference from the trial judge's statement is, "Had each of those things been different, I might have found a cure."

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And, otherwise, why should -- why would she go through these ventures?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So, that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- it doesn't seem to me -- for you to prevail, you have to take the extreme position that there can never be a cure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And when the trial judge --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- said they did not cure because they didn't do any of A, B --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- C, D, E, or F.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, it seems to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- it really seems to me you're adopting quite an extreme position, because it does seem to me perfectly obvious if, for example, they got a lawyer or brought his parents in, and they talked it over for 20 minutes and said, "We think he ought to do it." --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- you could -- you could surely  cure it in some fairness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Mr. Ravenell --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- let me tell you the problem -- the problem I have in the case --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and with your reliance on the trial court's findings.  I do not see how the fact that he's -- he's there in the cell in his underwear, the fact that he's 17, the fact that he thinks, and has been led to believe, erroneously, that there's a death penalty in the offing, has anything to do with the question that Edwards asks, which is whether the police, or this individual, initiated the conversation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That is the issue in these cases --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- whether the police initiated the conversation that produced the confession.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, I don't think so.  I think they go to whether the confession he gave was voluntary, but I don't see how they have anything to do with whether he initiated the conversation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- I think -- tell me if I'm wrong about this particular record.  I thought that the trial judge put it rather simply.  He said, "There was an interrogation by a police officer named Reese."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's conceded, as I understand it from Maryland --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that the police asked the question, and then the trial judge said the -- what Blake said was an answer to that question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's how she read what happened.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There was a question implying, "You'd better speak to us," and there was an answer to that question.  Not an initiation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that's what we're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- we're dealing with in this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So, your position, I guess, is -- I think it is, in your last answer -- that we really shouldn't be phrasing the inquiry in terms of the voluntariness of the suspect's statement, at this point.  We, rather, should be focusing it on whether the statement was, in fact, a spontaneous initiation on his part or a response to the preceding police statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's the way you would phrase the

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- issue for us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- absent of good-cop/bad-cop finding, and I -- and I repeat that they've credited Johns' testimony here -- this seems to me a very odd sort of interrogation, to say, "No, no, you -- we can't talk to him now."  That's an interrogation?  That's a stretch.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, is my --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- is my understanding of the Maryland law in effect when this happened correct that if you prevail on suppression, your client cannot face charges, no matter what the other evidence is?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- that law applies to this case at this time, correct?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Ravenell.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Graeff, you have 5 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How about the trial judge's determination?  There was a question.  Everybody agrees Reese - - what Reese did was interrogate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the trial judge then finds there was an answer to that question.  Is that a matter of fact?  It didn't seem that the trial judge was treating that as a matter of law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is it fact, or is it not fact, law, in respect to the following?  He's sitting there.  And there is a question of what motivated him.  Did it motivate him totally that his -- this thing about his codefendant, or was he moved, in significant part -- moved, motivated -- by the earlier, 30- minute earlier, improper questioning?  That sounds like a fact. Or do you think it's not a fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask one question before you sit down, if you're through?  Is it your understanding that the trial judge held that an Edward violation may not be cured, or that she held that, on the facts here, it was not cured?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So that, your -- the answer to your -- the question presented in your cert petition really is answered.  We all agree, it can be cured.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because the question you asked is whether it can be cured.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But you do agree --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- that the trial judge did assume  it could be cured.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And so, there could have been a cure.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If you lose this case, can the defendant be prosecuted federally under the carjacking statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the prosecutors were well aware of that when they determined to appeal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But perhaps they were worried that they didn't have a case without the defendant's statements.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Counsel. The case is submitted. [Whereupon, at 11:03 a.m., the case in the above-entitled matter was submitted.]
